thread.title: Balancing costs and growth strategy, DigitalGlobe cuts 2% of workforce
thread.title_full: Balancing costs and growth strategy, DigitalGlobe cuts 2% of workforce - The Denver Post

author: Laura Keeney
title: Balancing costs and growth strategy, DigitalGlobe cuts 2% of workforce
text:
Westminster-based DigitalGlobe today let go 40 employees — or about 2 percent of its total workforce.
"Essentially what we're doing is managing costs and continuing to grow," chief human resources officer Grover Wray said in an interview. "As any company does, they balance those two dynamics and we've made some decisions to help tighten our costs and invest in key new areas of growth."
Wray declined to specify those growth areas.
DigitalGlobe, one of the world's leading providers of high-resolution Earth-satellite imagery, posted second quarter revenue growth of 12.8 percent in June, with a net income of $8 million and an increase in government revenue of 18.4 percent to $113.1 million.

The company employs 1,256 people — about 1,200 in Colorado — and about 380 contractors across eight locations worldwide.
In February, the company let 155 people go, including 64 in Colorado, as part of what it said is an overall strategy shift.
The latest layoffs — about half of them in Colorado — fall across all areas of the company, including finance, legal, human resources and information technology.
There will be additional contractor job losses as well, Wray said, although he could not specify numbers.
Advertisement "We look at contractors in terms of total cost, not in terms of individuals," he said. "It's not possible to put exact number on contractor piece of that. It's an ongoing thing that continues to happen as we manage costs."
DigitalGlobe made attempts to move impacted employees elsewhere in the company, and Wray encourages those laid off to apply for the dozens of open positions listed on the company's website : "Like any organization, we continue to evolve every day, and every day we are looking to find opportunities for our people," Wray said.
Last year, the company launched WorldView-3, the most advanced commercial imagery satellite ever made and opened up its gallery of satellite images for sale, bringing a new revenue stream to the company.
DigitalGlobe in March moved into a new 482,000-square-foot Westminster headquarters from its previous home in Longmont. At that time, the company said it anticipated its Colorado staff would grow by approximately 400 employees, post-move .
The move to Westminster has been a good one for the company — the centralized location allows it to recruit across the entire Denver metro area, Wray said.
Tied to that move are state Economic Development Commission incentives for which the company asked in 2013, in exchange for keeping its headquarters in Colorado.
DigitalGlobe was granted up to $4.4 million in Job Incentive Tax Credits for the promise of adding 435 jobs, Office of Economic Development and International Trade spokeswoman Holly Shrewsbury said.
The Job Growth Incentive Tax Credit is equal to 50 percent of the company's 7.65 percent Federal Insurance Contributions Act tax on net job growth each year. Those credits are not provided to the company until the positions are hired and in place for a year.
Wray said projections provided to the state from the beginning of the incentive process are still in line.
It does not look like these layoffs will impact the company's incentives, Shrewsbury said.
